text:
hey! this is from a marketDefinition using the exchange stream, does anyone know the difference of these two time? does suspend indicate a delay?
`{'marketTime': '2020-07-10T02:20:00.000Z', 'suspendTime': '2020-07-10T02:20:00.000Z'}`

elements.text: hey! this is from a marketDefinition using the exchange stream, does anyone know the difference of these two time? does suspend indicate a delay?

text: Betfair times can be a bit confusing. Suspend time doesn't indicate a delay. Based on my observations I believe that it is the time that Betfair expects the markets to be suspended prior to going in-play (though the actual time that this happens will depend on the punctuality at the venue). So basically the same as startTIme, which is usually the same as marketTime - though very occasionally I've seen differences and haven't been able to work out whether they're meaningful or errors.

elements.text: Betfair times can be a bit confusing. Suspend time doesn't indicate a delay. Based on my observations I believe that it is the time that Betfair expects the markets to be suspended prior to going in-play (though the actual time that this happens will depend on the punctuality at the venue). So basically the same as startTIme, which is usually the same as marketTime - though very occasionally I've seen differences and haven't been able to work out whether they're meaningful or errors.

text: As an aside, I've never actually found a use for suspendTime, so the most practical answer might be to simply ignore it.

elements.text: As an aside, I've never actually found a use for suspendTime, so the most practical answer might be to simply ignore it.

text: Interesting! leaving it out certainly makes it alot easier.

elements.text: Interesting! leaving it out certainly makes it alot easier.

text: <@U9JHLMZB4> based on your observations, did you notice if a delay would change the marketTime?

elements.text: based on your observations, did you notice if a delay would change the marketTime?

text: I can't be absolutely certain, but I'm pretty confident that it doesn't.

elements.text: I can't be absolutely certain, but I'm pretty confident that it doesn't.

text: wishful thinking

elements.text: wishful thinking

text: It's not unusual when there is a delay (horses and dogs) to see trading continue, but as Liam has observed previously, the prices don't change much, suggesting that it's just bots ticking over. Prices don't tend to move much until the actual start approaches when real people get interested again and start moving the market. So I don't think there's amy way to detect a delay other than watching the actual events.

elements.text: It's not unusual when there is a delay (horses and dogs) to see trading continue, but as Liam has observed previously, the prices don't change much, suggesting that it's just bots ticking over. Prices don't tend to move much until the actual start approaches when real people get interested again and start moving the market. So I don't think there's amy way to detect a delay other than watching the actual events.

text: Noted, thank you.

elements.text: Noted, thank you.

text: Does anyone know how betfair decide the `adjustmentFactor`? It seems to be a fairly constant figure that rarely gets updated and I can't find any info on the "formula" used to calculate it.

elements.text: Does anyone know how betfair decide the
adjustmentFactor
? It seems to be a fairly constant figure that rarely gets updated and I can't find any info on the "formula" used to calculate it.

text: It will be similar to this - <https://help.tab.com.au/s/article/Tabcorp-Schedule-of-Deductions-for-Fixed-Odds-Racing-Betting>

elements.text: It will be similar to this -

text: Obviously using their own customised formula, which is unlikely to be shared

elements.text: Obviously using their own customised formula, which is unlikely to be shared

text:
<@U016535QCJ2> looks very similar, so probably another closely guarded secret.
I find this interesting: `Each horse is allocated a reduction factor, based on its *likely chance of winning the race*`
<https://support.betfair.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/408/c/483/>
I would _like_ to think that Betfair are using some sophisticated algorithm to calculate this value as it might effectively be a "true" price. What I don't understand is why Betfair use a fixed value for the reduction factor as surely it would be far more efficient to use the actual price of the runner when it gets withdrawn?

text: <@U016TGY3676> one problem with updating it constantly is that if you can get the information ahead of time you can manipulate the market (not sure if this somewhat happens currently)

elements.text: one problem with updating it constantly is that if you can get the information ahead of time you can manipulate the market (not sure if this somewhat happens currently)

text: I would guess they are forced to update it if the trading odds stray more than X% from the implied odds from the adjustment factor. Something ive never looked deeply into but would love to know more if someone else has.

elements.text: I would guess they are forced to update it if the trading odds stray more than X% from the implied odds from the adjustment factor. Something ive never looked deeply into but would love to know more if someone else has.

text: I'm not sure that this info is of any use to manipulate markets as it is only used when selections are removed (in the case of racing these are scratchings)

elements.text: I'm not sure that this info is of any use to manipulate markets as it is only used when selections are removed (in the case of racing these are scratchings)

text: So it is used when a random event happens that cannot be predicted - have never seen anyone do any analysis of this because I can't see how it would be useful
